data.title: Royal Society for Public Health UK
data.meta_description: Our annual awards ceremony celebrates achievement and best practice in public health
data.text:
Established in 2007, the RSPH Health & Wellbeing Awards is now the UK's premier awards scheme for promoting health and wellbeing.

The awards are, and always have been, free to enter

Each finalist will receive two free tickets to the RSPH Awards ceremony, where the winners will be announced

Previous winners have gone on to win funding bids, receive media coverage and attract new trustees and patrons

The awards ceremony will take place in London on 28th November 2024

The Health and Wellbeing Awards 2024 is now closed for entry. To register your interest for the next Awards, please click the link below.

The Awards recognise and celebrate a wide range of activities, policies and strategies that empower communities and individuals, improve the population’s health and address the wider social determinants of health.

The assessment criteria are based on the principles of the Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion and subsequent international declarations which call for action to achieve ‘Health for All’.

There are six categories representing the breadth and reach of public health projects and programmes:

Arts & Health Award

Community Health Development Award

Health & Wellbeing in Workplaces Award

Health at Every Age Award

Healthier Lives Award

Mental Health & Wellbeing Award

The Public Health Minister's Award

Developed in partnership with Department of Health and launched in 2014, the Public Health Minister’s Award recognises and rewards excellence and innovation in public health programmes delivered by organisations across all sectors and in settings such as workplaces, schools, care homes, hospitals and the community.

Entering the RSPH Health & Wellbeing Awards is the only route to the Public Health Minister’s Award – it cannot be applied for separately or independently. The winner is selected from the finalists of the RSPH Health & Wellbeing Award by a Department of Health Award Committee led by the Public Health Minister.
